node.text:
We had the incredible honor of speaking with the new Secretary of Education Dr. Miguel Cardona (@seccardona) about the Administration’s vision for kids and families, especially as it relates to equity. We discuss the American Families Plan and how it will invest in and support access to child-care, preschool, higher education and more.

We talk about the critical role HBCUs play in our country and why the @whitehouse is investing $39 billion into subsidizing tuition for students who attend them, the importance of investing into a more diverse teacher pipeline, and why access to free high-quality preschool and free community college matters.

Dr. Cardona is a father and lifelong educator with over 2 decades of experience as a public school educator. We hope you enjoy this conversation and stay tuned in to the work he'll be doing as Secretary of Education.

Please check out the link in our bio or Stories to learn more.

#TeachersOfInstagram #HBCU #Education

node.title: Special conversation with Secretary of Education Dr. Miguel Cardona

node.text:
Cleo Wade's debut and NYTimes best-selling picture book, What The Road Said, is not only a must-read, it is a comforting, wisdom-filled, and uplifting guide for kids to look to as they navigate their own journeys in life. We know it’s one kids will look to and revisit often for reassurance and guidance. It’s so valuable for all ages and stages of life and one that readers will be lifted up by through its encouraging and nurturing words. Reading this book feels like sitting down with a trusted and loving friend. 

We hope you enjoy this conversation about the book with @jennifer.garner as part of our @onceuponafarm Storyteller series. We also have 10 signed copies of What The Road Said to giveaway—please comment below if we can send you one.

node.text:
Talks to us about @virulenthate's newest report analyzing anti-Asian racism in 2020. The Virulent Hate Project identifies, analyzes, and maps incidents of anti-Asian harassment, violence, discrimination, and stigmatization, and researches trends in anti-Asian racism and Asian American activism. 

Their new report released this week examined over 4,337 pieces of news media on anti-Asian racism and found that of the incidents where the race of the perpetrator is known, they are predominantly male and disproportionately white. This is significant because the videos being centered and receiving mass circulation in the media and on social media have been creating a misconception that the majority of perpetrators are Black.

Dr. Borja speaks with us about the key findings of the new report, the ongoing trope of Black/Asian conflict and why it's important for us to think critically about how we may be reproducing that harmful narrative, how Black and Asian communities have been working in solidarity in response to anti-Asian racism, and how we can continue to show solidarity in the future and support our communities.

Special thanks to Dr. Borja for her time and for sharing her work and expertise with us! Please be sure to stay tuned for her next report on Asian American activism.

For more information, visit virulenthate.org. Dr. Borja is on IG and Twitter at @melissamayborja

node.title: Dr. Melissa May Borja, lead of the Virulent Hate Project

node.text:
Repost from @wongfupro
•
If you didn't know, May is Asian Pacific American Heritage Month. Although we're bringing attention to this in May, we hope the message will continue to resonate + be heard moving forward. Let’s keep on educating, speaking out, and uplifting. #StopAsianHate #APAHM

For more verified donation pages and organization fundraisers visit:
https://www.gofundme.com/c/act/stop-aapi-hate

node.title: PSA from our Asian Creator Community by @wongfupro via @goldhouseco

#aapiheritagemonth #aapihm #asianheritagemonth #apahm

node.text:
We partnered with @harryshumjr and @wongfupro to bring you a storytime playlist celebrating AAPI voices and experiences. Today, we are so excited to share the first read-aloud video with you!

Harry will be reading Grandpa Grumps by @katrinamoore1011 and @xindiyanart, published by @littlebeebooks. Please check it out now on the YouTube Kids app and our YouTube channel (linked in our Stories). 

We hope you love it and share it with your kids and students. Please stay tuned for new read-alouds each week this month featuring @padmalakshmi, @mingna_wen and Randall Park!

#AAPIStorytime #ReadAloud #AsianAmerican #AAPI #StopAsianHate

node.title: AAPI Storytime featuring Harry Shum Jr.

node.text: I Am Smart, I Am Blessed, I Can Do ANYTHING! In this special episode of #Storytellers, @jennifer.garner chats with @ayaandiop, the kid whose positive energy landed him a viral video of his walk to school, and inspired his mom, @alissa360style, and aunt, @AMomDotCom to write @ImSmartImBlessedICanDoAnything - a children's book that shows the importance of affirmations at any age. As @jennifer.garner reminds us, “All of us can benefit from taking a look at how we talk to ourselves.”

node.text:
From @tiffanyhaddish:
•
I was Working today for @kidssaythedarndestthings
Airing very soon on @cbstv . The Producers decided to tell me I WON a Grammy while I was interviewing these two young ladies Lauren and Ava, that want to someday be president of the United States of America. I was flooded with a such a since of accomplishment and relief. I kinda didn’t know what to say. I just wanted to cry but I knew it would have confused the babies. So I decided to use that moment to teach and share my feelings. Thank you @recordingacademy  for the honor. Thank you to everyone that made #blackmitzvah happen @pushitproductions @pagehurwitz #wandasykes #netflix #JackieKnobbe #Dionnewynn #yvettesheldon #LawRoach #jerrodcarmichael #lilrelhowery #chrisspencer #shereadyproductions #SHEREADY

node.text: It is our absolute privilege to host @SecondGentleman Douglas Emhoff in this very special story time. In celebration of Read Across America Day and Women's History Month, Mr. Emhoff is reading the book I Dissent: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Makes Her Mark by Debbie Levy and Elizabeth Baddeley. We hope you love it as much as we do! @simonkids

node.title: National Read Across America Day with Douglas Emhoff

node.text:
We are so excited to feature @meena in conversation with @jennifer.garner for this month’s @onceuponafarm Storytellers! 

Meena’s newest book, Ambitious Girl, is out tomorrow! It is an affirmation to young girls that they can do and be anything. It’s message of owning and living your purpose, not letting anyone tell you who you are, and being unapologetic about taking up space (in a world that too often tells Black girls and girls of color that they are “too loud” “too much”, and “too confident”) is deeply needed and important. 

In addition to Ambitious Girl, Meena also talks about her first book, Kamala and Maya’s Big Idea, and its message that no matter how small, each of us can make an impact. 

Please be sure to check out Meena’s movement and the incredible work she does in support of social and racial justice organizations with @phenomenal. Visit our Stories for the Once Upon A Farm blog post with links to Meena’s website and books.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by The Conscious Kid on July 17, 2021 tagging @floyd.cooper.4. May be a cartoon of 5 people and text that says 'CAROLE BOSTON WEATHERFORD. FLOYD COOPER UNSPEAKABLE THE TULSA RACE MASSACRE'.

node.text:
We are incredibly saddened to share that beloved children’s book artist and author Floyd Cooper passed away this week. He was a Coretta Scott King award-winning creator of over 100 children’s books — books that we have read, loved and been so grateful to share widely over the years. 

Floyd grew up in low-income housing in Tulsa, OK and started drawing at the age of 3. He attended all eleven elementary schools in North Tulsa and when teachers started noticing his drawings, they submitted his work to a scholarship committee. He was able to attend the University of Oklahoma on scholarship and went to work at Hallmark Cards after graduation. After much struggle, he got a contract with Penguin and published his first children’s book in 1988. He said, “Giving kids a positive alternative to counteract the negative impact of what is conveyed in today’s media is a huge opportunity” and he maximized it.

In addition to sharing everyday stories of Black life, joy and love, like the special bond between a grandson and grandfather in Max and the Tag-Along Moon, he also brought life to too often buried and suppressed stories in Black history — like how enslaved Black people built the White House in Brick by Brick, the devastation of the Tulsa Race Massacre in Unspeakable, the violence and indignities of Jim Crow facing Black travelers in Ruth and The Green Book, and a community coming together to challenge Maryland’s segregated amusement parks in A Ride to Remember. 

His stunning legacy lives on in his art and stories and we are full of gratitude for his life’s work and that kids will continue to learn and be lifted by it. Sending so much love and condolences to his family and loved ones. 

@floyd.cooper.4 ♥️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Conscious Kid on July 06, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'BLACK VOICES Nikole Hannah-Jones Rejects UNC UNC Tenure Offer, Will Teach At Howard University Instead Ta-Nehisi Coates will join the Pulitzer-winning journalist and creator of the "1619 Project" at the historically Black university as faculty. By Philip Lewis 07/06/2021 08:14 AM ET Updated 6 minutes ago f'.

node.text:
“At some point when you have proven yourself & fought your way into institutions that were not built for you, when you’ve proven you can compete & excel at the highest level, you have to decide that you are done forcing yourself in.

I fought this battle because I know that all across this country Black faculty, & faculty from other marginalized groups, are having their opportunities stifled, & that if political appointees could successfully stop my tenure, then they would only be emboldened to do it to others who do not have my platform. I had to stand up. And, I won the battle for tenure.

But I also get to decide what battles I continue to fight. And I have decided that instead of fighting to prove I belong at an institution that until 1955 prohibited Black Americans from attending, I am instead going to work in the legacy of a university not built by the enslaved but for those who once were. For too long, Black Americans have been taught that success is defined by gaining entry to and succeeding in historically white institutions. I have done that, and now I am honored & grateful to join the long legacy of Black Americans who have defined success by working to build up their own.

I will be taking a position as the inaugural Knight Chair in Race and Reporting at Howard University, founded in 1867 to serve the formerly enslaved and their descendants. There, I will be creating a new initiative aimed at training aspiring journalists to cover the crisis of our democracy & bolstering journalism programs at HBCUs across the country. I have already helped secure $15 million for this effort, called the Center for Journalism & Democracy, with generous grants from the Ford, Knight, & MacArthur Foundations, & have set a goal of raising $25 million. 

HBCUs have long punched above their weight, producing a disproportionate number of Black professionals while working with disproportionately low resources. It is my great honor to help usher to this storied institution these significant resources that will help support the illustrious, hardworking, and innovative faculty at the Cathy Hughes School of Communications & the brilliant students it draws.” —Nikole Hannah-Jones

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Conscious Kid on June 24, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Septima P. Snark @DrSubini Ok fam, real talk-l think we are taking the wrong turn in the Critical Race Theory fight: Instead of arguing it is not taught in schools or that scholar is not a Critical Race Theorist, we should be positively affirming Critical Race Theory's tenets & goals 1/'.

node.text:
Thread from Dr. Subini Annamma (Twitter: @DrSubini):

“Ok fam, real talk-I think we are taking the wrong turn in the Critical Race Theory fight: Instead of arguing it is not taught in schools or that __ scholar is not a Critical Race Theorist, we should be positively affirming Critical Race Theory's tenets & goals 1/

Of course they don't know what Critical Race Theory is and most of the scholars they point to are not Critical Race Theorists. We could answer that way, but that isn't the point. They are trying to erase any possibility of talking about racism in schools. 2/

We need to begin by asking folx who are mad at Critical Race Theory where racial inequities in legal, health care, ed & other sectors come from if they don't think they are systemic? Because they aren't saying it but they think those things are our fault. Make them say it 3/

Ask them about specific historical moments and how they would teach "both sides" (e.g., Juneteenth, Tulsa Race Massacre). Make them be specific. Ask them how Black & Brown children feel when learning about these things. Ask why white children would feel bad about these things 4/

Explain that we want children to have tools to recognize white supremacy as an ideology, how it is built into our systems. That should not make white kids feel bad, it should allow them to feel empowered to change the system. Explain that Critical Race Theory does just that 5/

Ask why they are afraid of all children knowing our history. Why are they afraid of Critical Race Theory giving us tools to talk about racism beyond individual interactions? Say "I may not be a Crtitical Race Theorist but I stand in solidarity with CRTs goals. Why don't you?" 6/

Don't get me wrong, folx have spoken out beautifully about what Critical Race Theory is & isn't, they have called out people who don't know what CRT is, they have pointed out that specific people aren't CRT scholars & that has all been powerful. I think it's time to shift now 7/7” (Cont. in comments)

#Education #TeachersOfInstagram

node.text:
Giveaway ✨✨✨
We are so excited to celebrate author @beneaththesheetz’s birthday with a special Bravo Anjali! giveaway. Pre-order this book TODAY (by 11:59pm PST) exclusively from the link in our profile and you will receive this beautiful poster (this art!!!) along with the book releasing September 14. Art by @luciasoto_com. Be sure to order extra - they make for great back to school goodies!

'I wrote this book to show our littles that they are limitless in every way. What better way to celebrate life than by celebrating our light?' (author, Sheetal Sheth)

In this follow up to one of our favorites, Always Anjali, Anjali navigates owning her excellence in playing the tabla while being the only girl in the room.
For Anjali, playing the tabla is something that comes naturally, but it seems like the better she gets, the meaner some of the kids are. 
Ultimately, Anjali realizes that she should never let anyone make her feel bad for being good at something. An important story for all children to remember to never dim their light.

ALSO! Tag a friend you love, follow @beneaththesheetz and @luciasoto_com and you will be automatically entered into a drawing to receive a free copy of Bravo Anjali! We will be randomly selecting 10 lucky winners!

Ages 4-10. @mangoandmarigoldpress **ONE DAY ONLY**

node.text:
A Juneteenth Reading List for Kids:

Juneteenth for Mazie by @floyd.cooper.4. Check out the link in our Stories for a read-aloud of this book. Ages 6-9.

Juneteenth by Vaunda Micheaux Nelson and Drew Nelson, illustrated by Drew Schroder. Ages 7-10.

All Different Now: Juneteenth, The First Day of Freedom by Angela Johnson, illustrated by E. B. Lewis. Ages 5-9.

#Juneteenth

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Conscious Kid on June 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'A JUNETEENTH READING LIST'.

Photo by The Conscious Kid on June 17, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Tuneteenth *FOR MAZIE* TLOYD COOPER Mazie is ready to celebrate liberty. She is ready to celebrate freedom. She is eady to celebrate great day in American history the day her ancestor were no longer enslaved. Mazie remembers the ongoing struggles and the triumph, as she gets ready to celebrate Juneteenth. Ages 6-9.'.

Photo by The Conscious Kid on June 17, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and text that says 'JUNE TEENTH IOLIDAYS BY VAUNDA MICHEAUX NELSON June 19th, 1865, began as another hot day in Texas. Then a message arrived. Freedom! Slavery had ended! The Civil War had actually ended in April. It took months for word to reach Texas. Still the joy of that amazing day has never been forgotten. Every year, people all over the US come together on June 19th to celebrate end of slavery. Ages 7- the 10.'.

Photo by The Conscious Kid on June 17, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'All Different Now Juneteenth, Û Day ofFreedom ANGELA JOHNSON Ilusd E. B. LEWIS Through the eyes of one little girl, All Different Now tells the story of the first Juneteenth, the day freedom finally came to the last of people enslaved in the South. Since then, the observance of June 19 as African American Emancipation Day has spread across the United States and beyond. Ages 5-9.'.

Photo shared by The Conscious Kid on June 17, 2021 tagging @b.scar, @tyrelldms, @nflpa, and @zbnfl. node.text:
Juneteenth is in 3 days so it’s a good time to re-share these language recommendations for writing, speaking, and teaching about slavery from P. Gabrielle Foreman and other Black scholars.

Tweet: @al0nte

Source: Gabrielle "Writing This Mghp" Might Û'.

May be an image of text that says 'Language to Consider Adopting/Preferred Terms: -Enslaved (Africans, people, mothers, workers, artisans, children, etc.) -Using enslaved (as an adjective) rather than "slave" (as a noun) disaggregates the condition of being enslaved with the status of "being" a slave. People weren't slaves; they were enslaved. -Captive (Africans, fathers, families, workers, infants, etc.) -Enslaver (The term "master" transmits the aspirations and values of the enslaving class without naming the practices they engaged) Source: Gabrielle Foreman "Writing This Mghp" Û document,June'.

Photo by The Conscious Kid on June 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Language to Consider Avoiding: Slave master -Slave mistress and enslaved mistress (to name sexual violence/relations/conditions) Slave breeding/breeders (for forced reproduction) -Slave concubine and enslaved concubine Slaveholder -Slave owner -Alternatives: those who claimed people as property, those who held people in slavery, etc. Gabrielle Foreman "Writing This Mighp" Might Û'.

Photo by The Conscious Kid on June 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Principles to Consider: -Avoid using "runaway slave." Alternatives: "fugitives from slavery" or "self-liberated" or "self-emancipated" individuals. Consider using not only the term "stolen labor," but also 'stolen labor, knowledge and skills." -No one was "born a slave"; instead people were born with "free" or "slave" status. Please honor the humanity of the millions of people treated as chattel property by naming enslaved people whenever possible. Source: Gabrielle Foreman "Writing This Mghp" Might'.

node.text:
“A year after the Supreme Court ruled that protections in the Civil Rights Act against discrimination in the workplace extended to gay and transgender people, the Education Department said on Wednesday that it has interpreted the court’s decision to mean that those protections also extend to students.

The department said that discrimination against gay and transgender students is prohibited under Title IX, a 1972 law that prohibits sex-based discrimination in federally funded schools. 

“We just want to double down on our expectations,” Miguel A. Cardona (@seccardona), the education secretary, said in an interview on Tuesday. “Students cannot be discriminated against because of their sexual orientation or their gender identity.”

The Education Department’s interpretation of Title IX is the opposite of the stance taken by the Trump administration, which maintained that transgender students were not entitled to protections and threatened last year to withhold federal aid from schools that allowed transgender athletes to participate in scholastic sports.” —Katie Rogers, NYTimes 

#ProtectTransKids #TeachersOfInstagram #LGBTQ #Trans #Education

node.text:
Cover Reveal ✨✨✨

We are so honored to share the cover of the forthcoming book EYES THAT SPEAK TO THE STARS from author @joannahowrites and artist @dunghanhho—the phenomenal creators of EYES THAT KISS IN THE CORNERS: 

“I was torn about writing EYES THAT SPEAK TO THE STARS because I believe strongly that all books are for all kids; there are no "girl books" or "boy books" and I had hoped that teachers, families and young people would be able to see themselves in EYES THAT KISS IN THE CORNERS regardless of their gender identity. However, I ultimately wrote EYES THAT SPEAK TO THE STARS because I thought about my son. I thought about how a lack of representation of Asians in literature is exactly that. A lack of representation. Invisibility. If I had an opportunity to add another story, to make multiple stories where so few have existed, to give people more choices in their representation, why wouldn't I take it? This is, afterall, why I became a writer.  There are so few positive examples of Asian boys and Asian men in the dominant narrative and that doesn't reflect reality at all. 

Additionally, I tried really hard to include in EYES THAT KISS IN THE CORNERS something about the bullying and discrimination - sometimes overt, sometimes subtle - that continues to plague Asian youth. I wanted to address it in some way, but ultimately had to take it out of the story because it was forced and didn't fit, no matter how I tried. EYES THAT SPEAK TO THE STARS, gave me another change to address this a little more directly. 

While I still hope that people don't gender their books; I also hope that this book offers some representation of the love and power that is passed in Asian communities through our fathers, grandfathers, brothers, and greater extended families. I hope my son will read it (and love the train that I asked the illustrator to include so he would actually read it! :-) ) and know his own power in the world.” —Author @joannahowrites

EYES THAT SPEAK TO THE STARS is available for preorder now (link in Stories) and will be released 1/2022. We’ve had a sneak peak and it is an absolute must-have for homes, classrooms and libraries. Ages 4-8. @harperkids

node.text:
Cleo Wade's debut and NYTimes best-selling picture book, What The Road Said, is not only a must-read, it is a comforting, wisdom-filled, and uplifting guide for kids to look to as they navigate their own journeys in life. We know it’s one kids will look to and revisit often for reassurance and guidance. It’s so valuable for all ages and stages of life and one that readers will be lifted up by through its encouraging and nurturing words. Reading this book feels like sitting down with a trusted and loving friend. 

We hope you enjoy this conversation about the book with @jennifer.garner as part of our @onceuponafarm Storyteller series. We also have 10 signed copies of What The Road Said to giveaway—please comment below if we can send you one.
